<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of producer_thread:
```c
static void *producer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (counter == COUNTER_MAX)
		metal_condition_wait(&nfull_condv, &lock);
	counter++;
	metal_condition_signal(&nempty_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function producer_thread:
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
...
#define COUNTER_MAX 10
...
static unsigned int counter
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments modify a function parameter variable (the pointer parameter itself), so none need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Specifically:

- producer_thread(void *arg): arg is only cast to void to silence unused-parameter warnings ((void)arg;). There is no assignment to arg or any modification of the parameter variable.

- metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv, metal_mutex_t *m): neither cv nor m (the pointer parameters) are reassigned or modified. The function operates on the objects pointed to by cv and m (e.g., atomic operations on cv->wakeups and cv->waiters, metal_mutex_release(m), metal_mutex_acquire(m), and syscall with &cv->wakeups). Modifying the pointed-to objects is permitted by the rule; only modifying the pointer variable itself would be a violation, and no such assignments exist (m is converted to an integer into a separate local mptr, but m itself is not changed).

- Calls in producer_thread such as metal_mutex_acquire(&lock), metal_condition_wait(&nfull_condv, &lock), metal_condition_signal(&nempty_condv), and metal_mutex_release(&lock) pass addresses of global objects; they do not modify any pointer parameter variable within the caller.

Because no function parameter variables are assigned to or otherwise modified in the provided code, there are no fragments that violate Rule 17.8 to report.
